questions.question_text: When developing a project schedule, which of the following resources is the BEST to estimate task duration?

comments.content: It doesn't say eliminate, it states "estimate". A scheduler may have no idea how long it takes to paint a 3000 sqft house because they've worked in a car manufacturing environment before. But you know who would be great as giving that estimated time? Yup the people who do it, the painters. This is a pretty easy way to look at it and hope it may help others in the future.
While I don't disagree with your answer here, the word "eliminate" is what threw a wrench in it for me. I think the only one who could just "eliminate" a task's duration would be a scheduler.

discussion.content:
This should be C - Project Team.

"The project team comprises the project manager, the project management team, and other individual team members. The individual team members perform project work and may not be involved in the management side of the project. The project team contains people from different groups who possess knowledge on specific subjects or have unique skill sets to carry out project work. The project team's duties include: 
- Use expertise to contribute to completing project tasks.
- Contribute deliverables on schedule.
- Provide estimates of task duration.
- Provide estimates of costs and dependencies."

Reference: Official CompTIA Project+ Student Guide (pg. 8)

B and C I could see.. But ultimately B

The project team members who are responsible for completing the tasks are typically the ones who have the most knowledge and experience with the tasks and can provide more accurate estimates of the duration. The project scheduler can use these estimates to develop the project schedule, taking into account dependencies between tasks and the available resources.

It's important to note that estimating task duration can be challenging, and there are many factors that can impact the accuracy of the estimate. It's essential to involve the project team members in the estimation process and to use techniques such as historical data analysis and expert judgment to improve the accuracy of the estimates.
